awd_titl_txt: Studies on the novel 5MP-ATF-4 pathway using insects as the model system
awd_abstract_narration:
The central dogma of molecular biology states that when genes are turned on, DNA makes RNA that makes proteins. The current understanding of how genes are turned on and off centers on the first of these steps: changing the amount of RNA produced from various regions of DNA genome (transcriptional control). The role of translational control through changing the amount of proteins made on RNA is less understood. This project will investigate the cell machinery that controls the first steps of protein synthesis on RNA. The researchers will investigate how mutations in some parts of this translation initiation machinery impair growth of neural cells and cause early death in animals, in particular insects.

One of the Eukarya-specific translation factor complex is the multi-initiation factor complex (MFC) made of four eukaryotic initiation factors, eIF1, eIF2, eIF3, eIF5 and Met-tRNAiMet. It plays essential roles in stringent translation initiation at AUG codon. Human eIF5-mimic protein 1 (5MP1) binds eIF2 and eIF3 through eIF5-mimic C-terminal domain and inhibits translation. Thus, this is the first protein that was identified as the potential regulator of the MFC function. An important consequence of MFC regulation (eIF2 inhibition) is to up-regulate the translation of ATF4, the transcription factor governing amino acid synthesis and stress resistance. In this project, cultured insect cell lines, including neuronal cell lines, will be used to study 5MP interactions with translational machineries and 5MP regulation of ATF4 translation. In the fruit fly, genetic evidence suggests that 5MP is involved in axon guidance. Using the second insect model organism Tribolium castaneum (red flour beetle), it is aimed at examining whether 5MP or ATF4 knockdown causes defects in axon guidance and determining which protein partner of 5MP can regulate this biological process and whether this is done through ATF4.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merits

In the central dogma of gene expression, DNA makes RNA that makes protein. Translational regulation determines the rate at which protein is synthesized by the ribosome using mRNA as template. However, how this is regulated and whether this is fundamental to higher eukaryotic function in development is not yet clear. To address these questions, we studied eIF5-mimic protein (5MP), a translational regulatory protein that binds the ribosome and associated initiation factors. 5MP is conserved in all eukaryotes except nematodes and yeasts. By using cultured human and insects cells in combination with genetics of four beetle and yeasts, we showed that 5MP controls translation of ATF4 transcription factor by a conserved mechanism involving upstream open reading frames in the ATF4 mRNA. Further studies also showed that 5MP regulates translation of cMyc transcription factor through repressing a new form of translation initiation involving non-AUG start codon. By regulating these transcription factors, 5MP can direct changes in transcriptional program generating distinct subsets of mRNA involved in determination of cell fates.

 

Broader impacts

Nine undergraduate students were mentored in this grant. Six of them became co-authors of five peer-reviewed articles generated from this grant. Two undergraduate and two graduate students were invited from Japan, helping them exposed to talented students with a different cultural background. Seven of these students presented their work in local scientific symposia. An undergraduate student presented her work in a major meeting held in Cold Spring Harbor Lab in 2016 fall. In March 2017, celebrating publication of their co-authored article in a major journal, they wrote a news article to K-State Today, an online daily news letter from the university.
